isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Chitin utilization by marine picocyanobacteria and the evolution of a planktonic lifestyle.
studies.description: Marine picocyanobacteria Prochlorococcus and Synechococcus, the most abundant photosynthetic cells in the oceans, are generally thought to have a primarily single-celled and free-living lifestyle. However, while studying the ability of picocyanobacteria to supplement photosynthetic carbon fixation with the use of exogenous organic carbon, we found the widespread occurrence of genes for breaking down chitin, an abundant source of organic carbon that exists primarily as particles. We show that cells that encode a chitin degradation pathway display chitin degradation activity, attach to chitin particles, and show enhanced growth under low light conditions when exposed to chitosan, a partially deacetylated soluble form of chitin. Marine chitin is largely derived from arthropods, which underwent major diversifications 520 to 535 Mya, close to when marine picocyanobacteria are inferred to have appeared in the ocean. Phylogenetic analyses confirm that the chitin utilization trait was acquired at the root of marine picocyanobacteria. Together this leads us to postulate that attachment to chitin particles allowed benthic cyanobacteria to emulate their mat-based lifestyle in the water column, initiating their expansion into the open ocean, seeding the rise of modern marine ecosystems. Subsequently, transitioning to a constitutive planktonic life without chitin associations led to cellular and genomic streamlining along a major early branch within Prochlorococcus. Our work highlights how the emergence of associations between organisms from different trophic levels, and their coevolution, creates opportunities for colonizing new environments. In this view, the rise of ecological complexity and the expansion of the biosphere are deeply intertwined processes.

publications.title: Chitin utilization by marine picocyanobacteria and the evolution of a planktonic lifestyle.
publications.authorList: Capovilla G, Braakman R, Fournier GP, Hackl T, Schwartzman J, Lu X, Yelton A, Longnecker K, Soule MCK, Thomas E, Swarr G, Mongera A, Payette JG, Castro KG, Waldbauer JR, Kujawinski EB, Cordero OX, Chisholm SW.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Prochlorococcus MIT9303 and MIT9313 cells were grown under constant light flux at 24 °C in artificial AMP1 medium comprised of natural seawater-based Pro99 medium containing 0.2-μm-filtered Sargasso Sea water, amended with Pro99 nutrients (N, P, and trace metals) prepared as previously described[1]. The low light experiment was performed at a light level of 1.5 μmol quanta/m^2/s. For the metabolomics analysis, Prochlorococcus cells were filtered under gentle vacuum (to prevent cell lysis) in a glass filtration tower onto 0.1 μM Omnipore filters (Millipore). Filters were then folded and placed into a cryovial, and frozen at -80 °C until processed. Half of the samples were amended with high molecular weight chitosan (Millipore Sigma) to a final concentration of 56 μg/ml. Samples were collected on day 4 and day 6 after inoculation for the metabolomics analysis. All the growth curves were performed in triplicate.


Ref:

[1] Moore LR, Coe A, Zinser ER, Saito MA, Sullivan MB, Lindell D, Frois-Moniz K, Waterbury J, Chisholm SW. Culturing the marine cyanobacterium Prochlorococcus. Limnology and Oceanography: Methods. 2007 Oct;5(10):353-62. doi:10.4319/lom.2007.5.353.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Intracellular metabolites were extracted using a method modified from a previously described protocol[1]. Briefly, the filter was extracted 3x with ice-cold extraction solvent (40:40:20 acetonitrile:methanol:water with 0.1 M formic acid), the combined extracts were neutralized with 6M ammonium hydroxide, and dried in a vacufuge until near dryness. Prior to liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC/MS) analysis, the samples were redissolved in 245 μl of solvent (30 μl Milli-Q pure water, 70 μl methanol, and 145 μl acetonitrile) with isotopically labeled injection standards (50 pg/μl each; d2-biotin, d6-succinic acid, d4-cholic acid, d7-indole-3-acetic acid, and 13C1-phenylalanine). The final extract volume was 150 µl. A pooled sample was generated for quality control (QC) by combining 25 μl aliquots from each sample.


Ref:

[1] Rabinowitz JD, Kimball E. Acidic acetonitrile for cellular metabolome extraction from Escherichia coli. Anal Chem. 2007 Aug 15;79(16):6167-73. doi:10.1021/ac070470c. PMID:17630720

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
Ultrahigh performance liquid chromatography (UPLC) was performed using an Accela Open Autosampler and Accela 1250 Pump, Thermo Scientific) coupled to a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (TSQ Vantage, Thermo Scientific). Separate hydrophilic interaction liquid chromatography (HILIC) methods were developed to separate metabolites in negative and positive ionization modes. For negative mode, a 2.1 x 100 mm, 2.7 μm Infinity Lab Poroshell HILIC-Z, P column (Agilent Technologies) was used. A mobile phase at pH 9 was prepared for gradient elution with 10 mM ammonium acetate in water (A) and 10 mM ammonium acetate in 90% acetonitrile (B) and pH adjusted with ammonium hydroxide. The additive medronic acid (5 mM methylenediphosphonic acid) was added to A and B at final 5 μM concentration to improve peak shape[1]. A sample volume of 5 μl was injected onto the column held at 30 °C, and eluted at a flow rate of 0.3 ml/min with the following gradient: hold at 90% B from 0 to 1.7 min, 90 to 60% from 1.7 to 10 min, hold at 60% B from 10.2 to 12.7 min, return to 90% B at 13.5 min, and equilibrate with 90% B till 20 min. For positive ion mode analysis, a 2.1 x 100 mm, 1.7 um Acquity BEH Amide column (Waters Corporation) was used. A mobile phase at pH 10 was prepared and composed of 0.1% ammonium hydroxide in Milli-Q water (A) and 0.1% ammonium hydroxide in 90% acetonitrile. A 5 μl sample volume was injected onto the column held at 40 °C, and eluted at 0.3 ml/min with the same gradient as above. The autosampler was washed between injections to prevent carryover with 2 successive wash solutions, 50:50 acetonitrile/water followed by 95:5 acetonitrile/water.


Ref:

[1] Hsiao JJ, Potter OG, Chu TW, Yin H. Improved LC/MS Methods for the Analysis of Metal-Sensitive Analytes Using Medronic Acid as a Mobile Phase Additive. Anal Chem. 2018 Aug 7;90(15):9457-9464. doi:10.1021/acs.analchem.8b02100. PMID:29976062.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: Mass spectrometry data was collected with a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (TSQ Vantage, Thermo Scientific) using a heated electrospray ionization source (H-ESI) in positive and negative modes operated under selected reaction monitoring (SRM) mode. Optimal SRM parameters (s-lens, collision energy, fragment ions) for each target compound were determined with authentic standards purchased from Sigma. 2 SRM transitions were monitored per compound for quantification and confirmation.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
Raw data files were converted from proprietary Thermo (.RAW) format to mzML using the msConvert tool[1], prior to processing with El-MAVEN[2], to integrate peaks for all samples and standards. Samples were analyzed in random order within each batch, and the pooled QC sample was analyzed every 6 injections. Metabolite concentrations were calculated using a standard curve of at least 5 points.


Refs:

[1] Chambers MC, Maclean B, Burke R, Amodei D, Ruderman DL, Neumann S, Gatto L, Fischer B, et al. A cross-platform toolkit for mass spectrometry and proteomics. Nat Biotechnol. 2012 Oct;30(10):918-20. doi:10.1038/nbt.2377. PMID:23051804.

[2] Agrawal S, Kumar S, Sehgal R, George S, Gupta R, Poddar S, Jha A, Pathak S. El-MAVEN: A Fast, Robust, and User-Friendly Mass Spectrometry Data Processing Engine for Metabolomics. Methods Mol Biol. 2019;1978:301-321. doi:10.1007/978-1-4939-9236-2_19. PMID:31119671.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description: Metabolites were identified by their unique retention time, parent m/z, and product m/z in comparison to authentic standards run using the same instrument method. The concentration of metabolites is given as fg per cell.
